text: Hi guys! I wonder if anyone has Julia running in a production environment or is it “only” used for scientific work. If you have it running productively, in what domain? I’m very curious about the answers!!

elements.text: Hi guys! I wonder if anyone has Julia running in a production environment or is it “only” used for scientific work. If you have it running productively, in what domain? I’m very curious about the answers!!

text: We're running Julia in production in Avast. It's not yet in the main pipeline, but it's running in kubernetes and interacting with other backends.

elements.text: We're running Julia in production in Avast. It's not yet in the main pipeline, but it's running in kubernetes and interacting with other backends.

text:
We run Julia for our largest and most important production system at Invenia. :invenia:
450K LOC code base, about 30-40 people working on it at any one time.

elements.text: We run Julia for our largest and most important production system at Invenia.
450K LOC code base, about 30-40 people working on it at any one time.

text: I’ve used it in production at Fugro for heavy geospatial data processing (point clouds etc) and am currently using it at a startup for simulation, machine learning, etc for economic modelling and optmisisation of businesses at ELARA AI. Multiple Julia developers at both.

elements.text: I’ve used it in production at Fugro for heavy geospatial data processing (point clouds etc) and am currently using it at a startup for simulation, machine learning, etc for economic modelling and optmisisation of businesses at ELARA AI. Multiple Julia developers at both.

text: <@U6A936746> At some point, it would be really nice to read a blog post about Julia in large-scale production. How do you manage the complexity? Tonnes of small packages for internal tasks that are independently tested? CI w/ integration tests? Build sysimages? That could be useful to other people about to embark on large-scale Julia projects

elements.text: At some point, it would be really nice to read a blog post about Julia in large-scale production. How do you manage the complexity? Tonnes of small packages for internal tasks that are independently tested? CI w/ integration tests? Build sysimages? That could be useful to other people about to embark on large-scale Julia projects

text:
I have written some  on it before.
<https://discourse.julialang.org/t/advice-on-structuring-larger-codebases/28203/17?u=oxinabox>

It is indeed tons of small packages. Private registry.
CI, integration tests only going upwards (unlike ChainRules which does downwards, which is harder since it is reverse depenency testing)
Night cron testing, to catch any breaking changes which slip through.
For production docker containers optionally with sysimages.


Interface Test Suites a a big one and we are using them more and more
<https://invenia.github.io/blog/2020/11/06/interfacetesting/>
(Blog post by <@ULQJQU4JZ>)
Current package I am working on is fairly small,
it has 3 interaface test suites of its own, and it calls two other interace test suites from other packages.

elements.text: I have written some  on it before.

CI, integration tests only going upwards (unlike ChainRules which does downwards, which is harder since it is reverse depenency testing)
Night cron testing, to catch any breaking changes which slip through.
For production docker containers optionally with sysimages.


Interface Test Suites a a big one and we are using them more and more

text: Neat, I'll take a look at it

elements.text: Neat, I'll take a look at it

text: My job title is "data scientist", but I'm responsible for some stuff in production and I've been using Julia in production for a few years.  Right now I am in the process of handing off one of my projects to my employer's engineering department, and it will be the first Julia code they officially maintain

elements.text: My job title is "data scientist", but I'm responsible for some stuff in production and I've been using Julia in production for a few years.  Right now I am in the process of handing off one of my projects to my employer's engineering department, and it will be the first Julia code they officially maintain

text: We also have several smaller packages, private registry and CI which tests all packages.  It works rather well, we have docker images for all stable versions of julia.

elements.text: We also have several smaller packages, private registry and CI which tests all packages.  It works rather well, we have docker images for all stable versions of julia.

text: the only special caveat I can think of about Julia in production as opposed to other languages is the usual elephant in the room, that being that ti's hard to produce statically compiled Julia code.  I *am* using PackageCompiler in production code, using compiled system images from unit tests

elements.text: the only special caveat I can think of about Julia in production as opposed to other languages is the usual elephant in the room, that being that ti's hard to produce statically compiled Julia code.  I
using PackageCompiler in production code, using compiled system images from unit tests

text: Betterment uses Julia in production for all our financial projections / recommendations. Our Julia advice engine handles around 18m requests per day currently, and much more efficiently than our previous engine (which was mostly in Javascript)

elements.text: Betterment uses Julia in production for all our financial projections / recommendations. Our Julia advice engine handles around 18m requests per day currently, and much more efficiently than our previous engine (which was mostly in Javascript)
